direction.raw_text: - (DAY) - (GLASS) This is December 24, 1944, in the first safe area directly behind the battle line, in the Italian theatre. In the distance occasional artillery light flashes are seen and artillery rumbles are heard.  The battered terrain shows the effects of battle. In the foreground is a recreation area, covered with camouflage; entertainment is in progress on a raised stage. Men of the division are seated about on benches, boxes, and the ground.  A camouflaged motor pool of jeeps and tanks is nearby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can HEAR LAUGHTER and APPLAUSE from the men as a jeep with two stars on the front indicating it is the General's car jounces along a road toward the side of the recreation area.  A YOUNG SERGEANT is at the wheel, an ADJUTANT beside him, and in the rear are GENERAL WAVERLY and GENERAL CARLTON.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - MED. CLOSE As it jounces along.  General Waverly is weather-beaten and weary; his uniform, while neat, shows the effects of long wear.  General Carlton, on the other hand, is stiff, clean and fresh from the Pentagon. He is staring off at the recreation area.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The jeep has come to a halt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Waverly and the Adjutant alight from the jeep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Sergeant looks at General Waverly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The jeep pulls off and makes a half circle. The Adjutant makes a gesture, as if to stop it. The General stops him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (To Adjutant) What's this all about, Colonel?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Turning) A little entertainment for the men, sir.  Tonight's Christmas Eve.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: These men are moving up tonight. They should be lined up for full inspection!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Eyeing him) You're absolutely right. (To Adjutant) There's no Christmas in the Army, Colonel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (To Carlton) There's always a slip-up or two during a change in command.  The men get a little loose.  But I know I'm leaving them in good hands.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Stiffly) Thank you. (To Driver) Sergeant, take me to headquarters immediately!  We'll have those men turned out on the double!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodbye, Sergeant.  Take the short cut.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Adjutant turns to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes the Adjutant by the arm and leads him toward the recreation area.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That's not the way to headquarters!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Joe, you know that, and I know that, but the new General doesn't know it. Or he won't for about an hour and a half.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That Sergeant'll be a private tomorrow!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes... isn't he lucky?
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.ToD: WHAT DOES A SOLDIER WANT FOR CHRISTMAS
result.heading: WHAT DOES A SOLDIER WANT FOR CHRISTMAS

direction.raw_text: - MED. SHOT CAPTAIN BOB WALLACE (BING CROSBY) is wearing a makeshift beard and Santa Claus hat and PRIVATE PHILIP DAVIS (DONALD O'CONNOR) is in combat clothes.  They are doing a number to entertain the soldiers, WHAT DOES A SOLDIER WANT FOR CHRISTMAS?  During introduction, we
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: just starting to take seats, off to one side where they are not noticed by the performers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: seated in audience.  They look off, see General, start to rise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The General notices them - motions for them to sit down again, indicating he doesn't want attention called to himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - FULL SHOT The number concludes to applause.  Bob holds up his hand for silence.  He removes his beard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Automatically, Bob stiffens.  Phil does the same.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks, fellows.  I guess by now you know the Old Man's being replaced by a new Commanding General fresh out of the Pentagon... this divisions's been awfully lucky so far, but tonight they're running a special on St. Christophers at the PX... The Old Man's heading back to the rear - he's never moved in that direction in his life.  All I can say is, we owe so much to General Waverly and the way -- WAVERLY'S VOICE (A bellow)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - FULL SHOT Every man is at attention and every head has turned to where General Waverly has taken up a position near the front of the platform.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boys respond with "Merry Christmas".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bob, covering his embarrassment:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns to the musicians, gives the downbeat.  They play THE OLD MAN, which is sung by the entire outfit. The General stands at attention through the first chorus, visibly moved.  During the second chorus he starts up the aisle, revealing for the first time that his left leg is bandaged to the knee. The Adjutant puts out his arm to help. Waverly refuses. Toward the finish of the song, he turns, faces the men and salutes them.  The men return the salute. (This is not a military mistake, the General salutes the enlisted men as a deliberate gesture.)  There is a Red Cross ambulance standing by.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Captain Wallace, button your shirt. You're out of uniform! (Bob, grinning, hastily buttons his shirt) This division is now under the command of General Harold G. Carlton, and I don't want anyone to forget it -- not that he'll let you.  He's tough -- just what this sloppy outfit needs. You'll be standing inspection night and day -- you may even learn how to march.  And if you don't give him everything you got, I may come back and fight for the enemy.  Merry Christmas!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Embarrassed) Well -- I guess that's about it - uh - uh --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps I can help you out, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: TINY CANDLE THE CAMERA PULLS BACK

direction.raw_text: - (NIGHT) - TINY CANDLE THE CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal a hand lighting a candle on a tiny makeshift Christmas tree.  We reveal a number of enlisted men huddled around the tree in a trench, including Bob and Phil.  One of the men looks at his wristwatch.  Now another does.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The hand is approaching midnight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is looking at his wristwatch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The second hand is pointing to the hour.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is the prearranged signal for Bob to begin singing WHITE CHRISTMAS.  Phil accompanies him on a harmonica.  Toward the end of the song, an enemy barrage DROWNS out the music.  A shell BURSTS in the vicinity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phil pulls Bob down in time to save him from the shrapnel burst.  This has also pushed Bob's face into the mud, which he thinks is unnecessary.  Phil, ignoring Bob's hostile look, brightly continues with WHITE CHRISTMAS from where the song left off.  Bob finishes with him, but eyeing him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (NIGHT)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: to the sky as brilliant fireworks explosion lights up the screen.  Over scene SUPERIMPOSE:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Headline reads: "V-E DAY!" As CAMERA MOVES FAST INTO headline, we LOSE the fireworks display and the headline covers the whole screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - (DAY) Bells are ringing for celebration of V-E Day.  CAMERA MOVES INTO mouth of one bell, blacking out the screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (NIGHT) featuring names and pictures of Bob and Phil.  CAMERA MOVES to a CLOSE SHOT of the picture, HOLDS for a second, then suddenly the picture comes to life and we are on the stage of the theatre where Bob and Phil are doing the production number "BELLS".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THEATRE - AUDIENCE Perhaps twenty people, photographed at a slant.  They're warm.  One woman has a fan, some use programs.  They are enjoying the show, however.  There are some vacant seats apparent.  This theatre is a modern traveling tent show, such as have been playing in Florida in recent years, and beyond the sides we see palm trees, characteristic of Florida.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the conclusion of the number.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FULL SHOT - BACKSTAGE The curtain is down, the boys come off, the curtain goes up on the next number, which is dancing.  Phil and Bob are met by COOKE, the Company Manager.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a luscious Latin type, and some of the remaining chorus girls and other players ad lib, "Couldn't be cuter!"  "Great." "Very funny!"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bob and Phil, with Cooke, go to the backstage telephone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (To Bob and Phil) New York's on the telephone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Into phone) Hello. (He listens.  To Bob and Cooke) Oscar.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT - INT. MANAGER'S OFFICE This is the business office of Bob and Phil.  OSCAR is their representative and manager, not their employer. He is sixty and looks competent.  He refers to a telegram in his hand.  Pictures of the boys adorn the desk, and Wallace and Davis sheets of previous shows are on the wall.  It must be evident from their billing that the boys are important stars in New York.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, I just heard what you're doing -- giving the cast a week off with pay for Christmas.  You don't know how touched I am.  I'm all choked up.  Between sobs, I managed to book you on the Ed Harrison show this week to take up the slack.  It'll be stealing money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Phil is holding the receiver up to Bob.  Oscar's VOICE can be plainly heard.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Into phone) We'll have to go to New York -- four days and four nights of rehearsals -- that's stealing money?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As he speaks into the telephone
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hangs up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It is for me  -- I get ten percent. (He listens for a moment) Next time you guys make a charitable gesture, find out if you got with what to make it.  See you Wednesday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Bob hangs up the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boys walk to their dressing room.  A group of the chorines come flying by, toward the dressing rooms, with squealing. They make quite a picture from the rear, bouncing and all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rita shows up in front of Phil.
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well... while the cast takes it easy we'll be slaving over a hot kinnie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What train do you want?  There's a one-thirty this morning but you have to sit up all night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's get out tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Eagerly) I'm ready.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Pretending that he is letting himself be pulled while he is still anxious to go in the other direction) I'm looking at them!  We're going in the wrong direction.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - BOB AND PHIL - (NIGHT) The boys are now finishing their dinner.  Bob is facing the orchestra, Phil would have to turn to see it.  The MUSIC plays, the boys eat.  The table is close to the bar.  On two stools sit JUDY and BETTY.  Betty is wearing her glasses and examining some railroad tickets that have just been handed her by the bartender.  Phil is not paying attention to his eating, he is entranced with Judy's pretty legs draped over the bar stool.  Bob cannot see the girls and is not even interested enough to turn around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT - BETTY AND JUDY On her part, Judy is not absorbed in the tickets, but is unobtrusively sizing up Phil.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Checking the tickets) We'll have to rush to get the 1:30 train.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you ever considered laying off the female sex for awhile?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What other kind is there? (He picks up the card which announces the performers names and reads) 'The Stewart Sisters.'  Sister act! (He smacks his lips. He doesn't realize that these two girls are the Stewart Sisters)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Down, Rover, down.  Remember, we have an agreement--you chase no new tidbits during the season.  You were man enough to give me your hand on it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You were sneaky enough to take it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Quietly) Ahem. (Judy's eyes are toward Phil.  A little louder) Ahem!  All right dear, relax.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's awful cute.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So was the one in Kansas City, and the one in Canton, Ohio, and the one in Waco, Texas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One of these days you're going to meet somebody extra cute and the next performance I'll be doing a single.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Sincerely) Nobody'll ever be cute enough to break up this sister act.

direction.raw_text: The audience applauds politely while the girls start toward the platform,  Phil reacts in surprise to the new development.

dialogue.raw_text: I haven't much luck with sister acts. They're all alike.  Shall I tell you what these two are like?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shoot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Four feet two inches tall.  Pudgy. Round races.  Have big bows in their hair.  Always smiling. (He parodies a smile) Lots of teeth.  Sister acts have more teeth than anybody else.  Two, three hundred teeth at a time.  The American Dental Association is investigating it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ladies and gentleman, the Stewart Sisters!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Remember that girl I told you about who got sick in St. Paul?  That's her!  The girl in the oxygen tent! I told you about her!  The road company of "Student Prince."  The whole company went to church and prayed for her!  It was the most touching thing I've ever seen in show business. (HE GETS UP.) I'll bring her over.

Toward the end of the vocal Phil dances Judy out to the terrace overlooking the water.  This blends into their dance.  The staging of the number should reunite the four principals by the end of the number.  The audience applauds and they all go back to their booth.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have to give another show.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: STAGEHAND is setting up a record on a record-playing mechanism backstage, as the group passes by heading for the dressing rooms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The girls have opened the door to their dressing room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The old burned rug routine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Kind of old fashioned, isn't it? I thought that went out with the Cherry Sisters. We'll have to do something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Hopefully) Got a flash?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A glimmer.  Have to stir it around a little.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We wouldn't want you boys to get into any trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As they all enter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As they close the door,
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?  Maybe we'll all wind up in the same cell.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Novello is with the SHERIFF and the LANDLORD.  The Sheriff is a husky fellow. At the moment he's eating an eclair and coffee, from Novello's desk.  The Landlord glares at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Novello puts his hand up, listening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gets up, opens the office door, and we HEAR their entrance music, as before, and the Orchestra Leader's voice, "The Stewart Sisters."
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That's the second dessert you've had, Sheriff!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Real good, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I haven't got all night to wait here while you eat free food!  You've got your warrant, arrest those girls!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Displeased) Now, we agreed to let them finish their show first.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't agree! (To Novello) That was his idea!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've got some rights, too.  You don't get those girls until after they've done their number!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, how long is it going to take?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait a minute! That's their music!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Bob and Phil stand with their backs to the audience. They turn, face front, and we realize they are mouthing to a record.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - RECORD PLAYER We identify that the music is coming from this spinning record player we have previously established.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bob and Phil do the number.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They APPLAUD at end of number.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NOVELLO'S OFFICE We faintly HEAR the applause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Sheriff gets up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: They're clapping! It's over!  Arrest them!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The boys bow themselves off, and run toward their dressing room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They hurry down the corridor, passing the office door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The office door opens behind them, which they do not see. The Sheriff steps out, followed by the Landlord and Novello.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Get out of these clothes! Toot sweet!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ma, unhook my bra!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Calm) Just a second, folks!  I'll handle this! (He walks to the dressing room door)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT - DRESSING ROOM DOOR There is a plaque attached to the key in the lock.  The Sheriff smilingly turns the key in the lock.  He puts the key in his pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The landlord is delighted.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Winking) You stay here.  Let them try to go through the window.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If they make a break for it, shoot 'em!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CAFE - (NIGHT) - SHERIFF The Sheriff walks around the corner of the cafe, and a police car awaits, with cop at the wheel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Sheriff continues to the window of our dressing room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Just a minute, Hank, couple of customers coming up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, boss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It opens.  The Sheriff watches it.  Out comes Phil's legs, meaning to get out backwards.  The Sheriff applies both hands and pushes back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pushes Phil in.  Nimbly, he raises himself in.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Back you go, boys!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DRESSING ROOM The Sheriff is in the room.  He looks coolly at the boys, who are now in their own clothes.  He stares at them.  They stare at him.  Recognition comes all at once.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all throw their arms around each other, pounding violently.  'No!  Wow!  You dirty skunk!  You grave robber!'
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Pete!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Phil!  Bob!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pete!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Unbelieving) Are you the Sheriff here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You bet I am!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How'd you get in this line of work?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: After I got out of the army I sat down and figured it out!  Who never got in trouble in the army?  The M.P.'s!  They were the ones who arrested you!  So I came back here and ran for Sheriff!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A civilian M.P.!  If the fellows ever saw you now!  They'd skin you alive!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You ever see any of them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whitey Harris and Jack Ross have a filling station near here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jack Ross!  Will you ever forget the party he threw in Naples?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In a captured brewery.  Very sensible, giving a party in a brewery.  Cuts out the middleman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you remember when Danny Beasly climbed up - (As he says 'Danny Beasly' he recalls Danny is dead) - the tower of the City Hall and rang the bell by swinging on the clapper?  He couldn't hear anything for two days.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Danny Beasly!  Too bad he didn't make it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not everybody was lucky.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We were lucky in one thing - the old man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can say that again.  Say I'm supposed to arrest a couple of dames! A fellow swore out a warrant!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's a crook!  Burned a hole in a rug and is trying to hold up two kids.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't say!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (At his watch) We got to get our bags and be at the station in ten minutes!  We'll never make it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just a moment! (He goes to the window) Hank !
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - SHOOTING BY SHERIFF Hank looks up enquiringly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take my friends where they want to go!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hurry up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Going out the window) Thanks, Pete.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Hank has thrown the door open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts with his red lights going, his siren screaming, and tires grinding.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Do you think we can make it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This thing goes over a hundred an hour!  Hold on!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DRESSING ROOM The Sheriff watches them go, pleased.  A pounding on the door recalls the Landlord, and he frowns.  He strides to the door, takes out his key and opens it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Landlord and Novello are looking out the window at the departing police car, the noise having distracted them from the door pounding.  The siren is still heard, retreating. The Sheriff snaps his cigarette at their feet.  They turn to him, faces alight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He protests, 'What - !' 'But!'  Novello is openmouthed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: They escaped!  We're pursuing 'em!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Escaped!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Pointing) What do you mean smoking on theatrical premises!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's not mine!  I wasn't smoking!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's that burning?  A lollypop? (He grabs him by the shoulder, not too gently, and starts him out) Come on!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (NIGHT) The train is already moving as the police car arrives. The girls are on the observation platform.  The police car screams to a stop.  The boys fly out, with bags, and just make the train, the girls pulling them aboard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They go toward the lounge car.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Seriously) You didn't steal the police car?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no.  Friend of ours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . LOUNGE CAR - GROUP They all take seats in the lounge car, happy to have accomplished their escape.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bob looks from him to Judy, whose expression is almost pleading.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, we'll be together as far as New York.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe it'll snow in New York for Christmas.  If it doesn't, we'll mail you a snowball from Vermont.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I haven't been on ice skates in years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ice?  You mean the stuff in a Scotch and soda? (Suddenly) Bob, how about snow for Christmas?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll only thaw it out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, Bob, we could have a great week up in Vermont.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see what you mean.  But Wednesday we've got to be back in New York.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right -- so it's just for a couple of days.  Don't you want me to enjoy the winter sports?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You enjoy them all year round. (He looks to Betty) We won't get in your way, will we?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As long as your friend doesn't try to take my sister for a sleigh ride.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If he tries it, I'll smash his flexible flyer. (To Phil) It's all set.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Really pleased) The thing I like about you, Bob, is you're not only kind and generous, you're handsome.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're going to have to sit up all night.  Let's get some shut eye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . TRAIN - (NIGHT) The rhythm of the wheels and the engine funnel, underscored musically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TRAIN All but Phil are half dozing.  One or two other people are seen in the background, asleep.  There is an air of peace and quiet in the car, as the music underscoring continues. Their faces are occasionally streaked with light flashes emanating from the surrounding countryside.  Phil turns to the side of the car and sees a bill poster showing a copy of a winter scene from the Grandma Moses collection, advertising Vermont.  CAMERA PULLS UP TO scene, the music swells and we DISSOLVE to a similar landscape in stylized concept.  This is the WINTER FANTASY production number.  At the end of the fantasy we hear the Conductor's voice, "Pine Tree.  Pine Tree, Vermont."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - (DAY) They are bundling themselves up, coat collars tight, expecting to enter the snow country.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pine Tree Station, all green, no snow.  Four hotel busses await, one marked 'Columbia Inn Bus.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - (GLASS SHOT) Our foursome is just getting off the train.  They are the only ones.  They are looking about, puzzled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The other three bus drivers are disappointed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Are you sure this is the right Vermont?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This isn't a southern Vermont?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't understand it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There has to be snow!  This place is advertised as America's Snow Playground!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, if you say so. (Gesturing to the waiting Columbia Inn bus driver) Driver, your sleigh and reindeer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The bus goes by an incongruous skating rink, with water instead of ice.  Signs indicate the direction of the sun scorched toboggan slide.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bus winds around another turn in the beautiful green surroundings and we pass a ski lift and a ski jumping platform.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still another turn of the bus, and in the distance we see a LONG SHOT of the Columbia Inn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COLUMBIA INN MARTHA, a sixty year old spinsterish woman, good of heart, forbidding exterior, is occupied at the desk. The door opens and a pretty fifteen year old, SUSAN, carrying the mail, walks toward her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She puts the mail on the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Through the huge window behind Susan and Martha we see the figure of a man in overalls, bending over an incinerator, shoveling the ashes into a wheelbarrow. His back is to CAMERA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Susan starts out as CAMERA MOVES UP to window.  After a moment, Susan appears and crosses to the man in overalls. He straightens up, dusts off his hands, and as he turns to take the letters, we see for the first time that he is General Waverly.  He looks through them, eagerly, then, downcast, shoves them in his overalls and goes back to his work.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mail, Martha.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (As she shuffles through it) What's the weather forecast down at the Post Office?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Awful.  Fair and warmer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If we don't get snow soon we can turn this hotel into a haunted house. We haven't had a guest for three weeks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (As Martha keeps searching through the mail) What are you looking for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Not finding it) Your grandfather's written Washington asking if he can get back in active service.  I think he wants to fly jets.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think he could do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He says older men have been called, and besides, he misses the food.  I tell you, Susan, he tried to make it a casual letter, with little jokes, but it came out just begging.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Moved) Oh, Martha!  What are we going to do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Blowing her nose) I don't know.  Don't let on we know he's written.  He'll start in I'm only his housekeeper and that I found out through some chicanery or something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Soothing her) How did you find out?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like any housekeeper --  I read the carbon paper. (She hands the mail to Susan) Bring him the mail.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . INN - (DAY) The bus comes to a stop and our principals get out, Phil staying with the driver for the luggage.  The others enter the inn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INN Martha at the desk, and her eyes widen in surprise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Through the door comes Waverly, carrying a load of wood in one arm, and a bucket of coke in the other hand.  Susan follows carrying an armful of kindling. Bob turns away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Through the door comes Phil, fast, talking:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phil has his arm out indicating the direction of the door, when he sees Waverly.  He freezes.  He brings his hand up to a salute, from that position.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phil and Bob stiffen automatically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiles at the girls, and exits, dignified.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Happily) Welcome to Columbia Inn.  How do you do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do you do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Offering pen) What kind of accommodations would you like?  We can give you a fairly wide choice--any room in the Inn, including mine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're not here as guests.  We're the Stewart sisters.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Disappointed) Oh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My friend and I are guests.  We've come down for the snow.  Where are you keeping it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We take it in during the day!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Looking around) What are your rates here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Make us an offer. (To the girls) I'm afraid we won't be able to use you.  We'll pay you the half salary for canceling.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, no!  Are things that bad?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're using the ski-tow to hang the wash on. (To Bob) You're not going to stay either, are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Shaking his head) I'm afraid not, ma'am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll tell Phil to leave the luggage - (It hits him, he comes to a stop, and then to attention) General Waverly!  Sir!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Easy, simple) At ease!  How are you, Captain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm fine, sir. (But he looks around questioningly, bewildered)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Smiling) We just try to keep the General part quiet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why? (Reminding himself) Begging your pardon, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, to put it in one sentence, people don't expect major generals to carry firewood.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bob, I was thinking we ought to -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At ease!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, sir! (Horrified) A janitor!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never thought I'd make it, he? ...Matter of fact, it's worse than that.  I own this hotel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He got it in a shrewd business move.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (To Bob) Was everybody in your outfit?  We seem to run into them all over the country.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Draft Board didn't know when to stop.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I start the introductions, can I get to meet these young ladies? (Indicating them) My housekeeper, Miss Martha Allen, my granddaughter, Susan Waverly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm Bob Wallace -- this is Phil Davis -- BETTY We're the Stewart sisters.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your floor show.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (To Waverly) Don't worry -- I've already told them we'd have to cancel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?  We have a floor, haven't we?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Last time I looked.  But who are they going to sing to?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Even if it's only to you and me, it will be well worth it.  Besides, there will be six inches of snow tonight and we'll be full up tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Happily) Is that the weather forecast?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.  But if there was one thing I learned in the army it was to be positive -- especially when you don't know what you're talking about. You'll excuse me, gentlemen, I'm on K.P.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (To Betty and Judy) And you two charming ladies, I want you to know I'm looking forward to your show this evening.  Whatever your audience lacks in numbers, it will make up for in enthusiasm -- (He glares at Martha) or I'll know the reason why!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Utterly charmed) Gee... no wonder we won the war!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (NIGHT) - MED. CLOSE SHOT - BETTY AND JUDY They are doing the number, SISTERS, on the floor.  THE CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal the scene.  There is a scant audience distributed at several tables, totaling not more than fourteen in number.  Not far from the kitchen entrance Bob and Phil are sitting at one table. Martha is seen doing general overseeing, principally acting as hostess.  Susan doubles between the cashier's desk and helping out at table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT - BOB AND PHIL They are admiring the performance.  Phil indicates for Bob to look in this direction.  Bob does.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SNOT The General is seating a table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bob shakes his head, unhappy at this condition.  They look at each other.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I think well stay a little longer than we planned.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . FULL SHOT - BETTY AND JUDY They finish the number and are applauded enthusiastically, but the few people in the audience don't make for much clatter.  One set of hands seems to be applauding loudest and clearest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is the one doing the enthusiastic applauding.  He walks toward the boys, still applauding.  They applaud too.  The girls enter the scene, to sit with the boys. Martha is only applauding politely, until Waverly glares at her.  Then her enthusiasm is boundless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A waitress brings food, which Martha helps distribute.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He dignifiedly walks in the direction of some departing guests, and proceeds to show them to the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he regards Bob with something akin to awe, we
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Excellent.  I enjoyed it very much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was nice, if you like music.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (After a look that the waitress is not in a position to hear) Mister Waverly, we'd like to make you a proposition.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Smiling) Well, for heaven's sake!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've been very nice not canceling, we'd like to make a gesture.  Until it snows, and you have guests, we'll take half salary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Appreciative) That's really nice of you. (She takes out pencil and her order book) Now let's get that in writing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Pushing it aside) Never heard of anything so ridiculous. (Gets up) Your next performance is tomorrow night, after dinner.  Be here, or I'll sue!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Annoyed) Light-Horse Harry.  Advance, advance, never retreat!  He's advancing right into bankruptcy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's just the way he was in the army.  Always thinking of the other fellow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We ate and then he ate.  We slept, and then he slept.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then he woke up, and nobody slept for the next forty-eight hours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I happen to know he's sunk his life's savings into this place.  I read the carbon paper.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gee, I wish there were something we could do to help.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe there is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You got a flash?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A glimmer.  Have to stir it around a bit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (To the girls) Shhh! (Indicating Bob, tapping his forehead) Ticking away madly.  Wheels within wheels.  This is the brain that, in darkest Italy, devised a formula to make food out of K-Ration!  Shhhhhh!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . LOBBY - (NIGHT) The last of the supper audience is leaving.  We see into a room which adjoins the reservation desk and Bob is on the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INN OFFICE Phil is sitting on the desk while Bob talks.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Into phone) Relax... I didn't ask you how much it'll cost us... (We hear an excited high voice on the phone) Easy, easy, remember your blood pressure... I don't care how much it'll cost us... That's better... Have everybody on the train first thing in the morning.  The whole Troupe, and the scenery, and the costumes... You'll have to cancel us off the Ed Harrison Show...  Oscar, remember your blood pressure. Incidentally, how much will this cost? (He hears some figure. - It obviously is a very large number) Good night, Oscar. (He hangs up) There you are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Incidentally, how much will this cost?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Clears his throat) We are coming out - even.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean flat?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's the same as even.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wheels within wheels.  It's nice how you take care of the money for both of us because you're older and so level headed.  I wonder where I'd be now if hadn't saved your life?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you want me to cancel the troupe coming?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Getting off the desk) No, no.  Let's go through the gesture. If you had been on the Titanic when it went down, you wouldn't've been satisfied just to sink into the ocean. (Gesturing) You'd have done a swan dive into it. With me on your back!

The notion behind this scene is to be able to hear only intermittent dialogue due to the whistle, bells, and escaping steam.  The manner of playing, though, indicates the sentiment.  To emphasize it: Bob is fonder of Betty than he realizes, and Betty fully realizes how fond she is of him but that he does not return, consciously, her affection.  We hear Betty:

direction.raw_text: Not all of this is heard, since the sound effects pick their spots, but the attention is on the General, who is watching the scene with a whimsical look.  He, as does the audience, realizes Bob's true feelings.  As the train starts to leave, Betty and Bob shake hands.  She holds his handshake a little longer than necessary, and Bob is forced to move along with the train.  Finally she releases him, and Bob looks after the train, puzzled.

dialogue.raw_text: Don't leave me!  Everything is going round and round!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nobody's leaving you!  Martha, get me a cold towel!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT - INT. TELEVISION STATION ED The objective is Pine Tree, Vermont --- Synchronize watches for Operation Waverly...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . OFFICE Phil has his eyes closed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Waverly takes the wet towel from Martha.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Waverly slaps the towel on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Judy bursts into the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phil assumes a pain-stricken face again and Judy throws her arms around him.  Phil smiles over her shoulder at Waverly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Things still going around?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now they're going sideways!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now they're going in and out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This'll bring him out of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Sitting up) Where am I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Phil, what's happened to you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - NIGHT - COUNTRY ROAD Silhouette of busses, Station in background, if desirable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FULL SHOT - FORK IN ROAD Two men, with M.P. armbands, slow up the busses.  One is revealed to be Phil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The busses move on.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: .P. All quiet, folks!  Entering the town!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Old Man's asleep!  Let's keep him that way!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - NIGHT - INT. LOBBY Bob and Betty tiptoe through the entrance to the inn.  In the semidarkness of the lobby we hear a "sst - ", and Susan and Martha are revealed having been waiting for them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martha blows her nose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks to Susan and she begins to bawl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bob looks to Betty for support.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She can't hold it back either, and now the three women are crying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They start out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We've been waiting for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How is everything going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They are bedded down in all the hotels.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His old outfit... If I wasn't such a mean old biddy, I'd probably break right down and cry. (She cries)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's nothing to cry about, is there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Through the crying) Thank you so much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can't you do something?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're just affected by the gesture.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Through her tears) Where are Judy and Phil?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Probably in their rooms, crying.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BUNGALOW - NIGHT As Bob and Betty turn around the corner, they see Phil and Judy, locked in an embrace.  Bob has been in front, but he steps back quickly, not wanting to embarrass the lovers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She walks into sight, Bob following.  Phil and Judy break, embarrassed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he holds his hand out, and they shake hands, still flustered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Flustered, the boys open the door to the girls' bungalow, thinking it is their own.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all laugh.  The girls enter their bungalow and put on the light.  The boys head toward their bungalow.  Phil enters in a gay mood.  Bob stops at the door, turns around and looks toward the window of the girls' bungalow.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Who is it?  General Waverly?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The lovers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (To Bob) We can't just stand here.  We have to get some sleep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We were rehearsing for the show tomorrow night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is it going to be that kind of a show?  We'll be raided!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you doing here?  What happened at The Carousel?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm helping out here tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi, Bob. Everything's under control. (Fluster) I mean with the show. We've got a lot of new material.  You both are going to have to do a lot of rehearsing. (Flustered again) I mean the other kind of rehearsing - I mean - rehearsing  Well, good night, Judy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good night, Phil.  Good night, Bob.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (To both) Good night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's get out of here before the gossip starts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . GIRLS' BUNGALOW - NIGHT Judy is getting into bed.  Betty, in her dressing gown, is looking out of the window toward the boys' bungalow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Betty throws her a look, and exits.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Bob is still pacing up and down on the porch... I think I'll go out and see what's bothering him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's how I started in Canton, Ohio.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is Vermont.  Nothing can happen here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Keep your guard up... That ain't Coolidge out on that porch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Bob stands on the porch, in robe and slippers, thoughtfully puffing at his pipe. Betty comes into scene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Betty comes up on the porch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She starts to sing, COUNT YOUR BLESSINGS.  At the conclusion, she walks away, leaving him standing there.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What are you doing?  Sleep walking?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Turning) Couldn't sleep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whatever you've got on your mind isn't worth staying awake for.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where have I heard that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell you how I handle a situation like this, Doctor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - (NIGHT) This sign announces the show opening.  People are streaming into the inn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WAVERLY'S QUARTERS The General is in his dressing gown, furious. Martha and Susan are playing a part.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stalks out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How could you send all my suits to the cleaners?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've only got two.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why can't you wear your uniform?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I won't appear in uniform!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, Gramp.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Absolutely not!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very well.  I'll explain to Bob and Phil that you didn't care to come to the show tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll have you court-martialed!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't mind being ungrateful, you just don't like being told you are!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Follows it up) If you think you don't owe them anything, you're not obliged to go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They haven't done much for you. Hardly anything.  You do what you think is right!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Angrily) Martha, I'll make my own decisions! I got along very well in the army without you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It took 15,000 men to take my place!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - (NIGHT) It is slowly filling up.  One of the guiding officials turns out to be the Sheriff we have previously seen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Seating a party) Right this way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . MAKESHIFT DRESSING ROOM - BOB AND PHIL They are getting into their old uniforms, which are slightly misfit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bob takes a deep breath and gets the top button buttoned.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (At the trousers) This thing's shrunk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Looking at the bulge) Pants always shrink in closets.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't breathe in this.  What am I going to do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know what I'm going to do. (Showing him) I'm going to take one big deep breath, and that's going to be it for the next three hours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - (NIGHT) General Waverly comes down the stairs, cutting quite a figure in his uniform and decorations.  Martha and Susan, waiting for him at the bottom, look him over, admiringly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Gruffly) Well, I couldn't come down in my bathrobe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The spotlight prepared, pinpoints the General as he enters the room, and the music starts.  The audience rises and applauds.  He can't believe it.  He reaches his table, decorated with flowers, and recognizes he is the guest of honor.  From the lobby we hear the outfit SINGING the opening strains of THE OLD MAN. All eyes turn to the lobby entrance, through which the old outfit marches, and continues to the stage, and then back to their respective tables as the song finishes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is profoundly moved and walks to the stage.  The audience is seated.  Waverly looks at the assembled crowd with great affection.  The people begin to shout, "Speech!  Speech!" Martha and Susan sit. The crowd quiets, waiting for the speech.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They howl and cheer.  He makes has way toward his own table, greeting old friends on the way.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (He must have had a blood transfusion from a sergeant at some time) I am not satisfied with the conduct of this division!  Some of you men are under the impression that having been at Anzio entitles you not to wear neckties!  You are wrong! Neckties will be worn in this area! I have also noticed a deterioration in the quality of saluting!  This is to be improved!  I have also had complaints from the commanding officer of the rest area in Naples!  He informs me that the non-fraternization rule is constantly being broken by men of this division!  In fact, this division is outstanding in its violations of non-fraternization! You all know the rules!  The non- fraternization ban expressly declares you are not to talk to women! (A slightly different tone) Don't talk to them!  That is all!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT - BOB AND PHIL As they step to the front of the stage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phil looks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is the cue for the orchestra to start the production number, I WISH I WAS BACK IN THE ARMY.  At end of number -
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (To the audience) Doesn't that bring back memories? Remember those terrible, trying days in Italy... when we had to beat the women off with chocolate bars?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And wasn't it awful the way they kept bothering us for American cigarettes?  Why, I must have taught fifty girls how to smoke...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For a month's pay all we got was 950 million lira...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nine hundred and fifty two...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was forced to hire a caddy for my loose change.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fore...!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm glad I'm well out of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: I WISH I WAS BACK IN THE ARMY

dialogue.raw_text: Who are we kidding?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - FULL SHOT As they applaud and cheer.  The old outfit is happy. In the exultation, General Waverly places two fingers to his lips and blows a whistle of sheer pleasure and approval.  We underscore with MUSIC indicating another number is taking place on stage, although we do not see it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - MED. CLOSE Ed Harrison crosses to General Waverly and whispers to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Waverly looks surprised, but rises and starts out. Bob, visible in b.g., has been watching.  He and Harrison exchange knowing glances.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Long distance call for you, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - MED. SHOT The lobby is empty;  in b.g. are the doors to the dining room, where the show is in progress.  The telephone lies on the counter.  Waverly enters and crosses to it.  He is a little annoyed at being forced to leave the entertainment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He suddenly snaps to attention, the old soldier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Through the window behind the General we have seen it begin to SNOW.  The General notices it for the first time, and his face brightens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hangs up the phone, and proudly, head erect, he walks through the lobby, smiling, eyes wet.  He lifts the bell on the desk with a loud bang.  Martha hurries in, startled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martha salutes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She and the General gaze at the snow falling beyond the lobby door which is blown open by the wind. Underneath all this we have been hearing the introductory music to WHITE CHRISTMAS, which is the number now in progress on the stage.  Waverly now turns and walks into the dining room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Into phone, gruffly) Hurry up, hurry up, I'm busy. Yes, this is General Waverly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Quietly) And a Merry Christmas to you, Mr. President... Yes, practically the whole outfit is here.  A little paunchy, but they're here.  It certainly was a surprise -- more like a frameup.  As usual, my Intelligence was not functioning efficiently... Yes? (Long pause) That's very nice of you, Mr. President... any time you want me, just say the word... but may I add this?  It isn't always necessary to take a job... sometimes it's enough just to know it's there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you ever take it into your mind to grab a little rest from all that work I wish you'd drop in on us here -- I can't promise you any golf but -- (As he looks at the falling snow)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: we can certainly give you plenty of snow, Mr, President... Yes, Mr. President... What? (Smiles) Thanks, Ike.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You frightened me to death!  That bell hasn't been used for three months!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get this area policed up.  No telling who might be dropping in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: CAMERA
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Waverly on his entrance.  As he passes Susan, we see she is reacting to something on the stage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Waverly and moves to:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - FULL SHOT - MOVING CAMERA Center stage, there is a large cutout of a decorated Christmas tree.  Also, there is considerable Christmas holly, mistletoe, etc.  Bob and Betty are seen singing.  Throughout action of this number Phil and Judy dance.  In addition there is staged movement by the ensemble.  Bob and Betty are on each side of the cutout Christmas tree, but it is obvious that Betty is preoccupied with some stage business which she is manipulating with one hand behind the cutout tree.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bob and Betty as their movement takes them behind the tree.  It is now that we see very clearly that the rear wall of the stage (two immense barn doors) has opened; in b.g. we see the Vermont countryside being covered by the falling snow.  Also, we see pine trees in the snow that are decorated. Betty steers Bob to a point directly beneath a sprig of mistletoe from which is also hanging the mate to the sock she gave him in scene 110.  Bob looks up, sees the mistletoe and the sock, and smiles at Betty. She lifts one of his trouser legs and we see that he is wearing the other sock.  They laugh and embrace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The cutout tree onstage rises to the flies and now the real trees and falling snow in b.g. are completely visible.  One by one, the trees are lighted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - MED. CLOSE Martha and Susan are standing happily beside the General, each holding one of his arms.
direction.name: direction
